author: tehnoodles
body:
At a very small scale software like DNAC or DCNM works ok. Try to scale this to 10,000's of nodes, and it starts to fall apart. I have seen this multiple different times, and this was using recommended compute hardware given to us by cisco to try and make it work.

The automation software crumbles when you reach scales the require automation, which completely defeats the purpose.

I also didn't say their hardware has issues. Aside from the usual bug schedule (which cisco is no better/worse than anyone else) their hardware is rocksolid, it really comes down to the software for the API on the devices, or the software of tools to manage it.

Cisco is only a leader in the market when you look at the entire breadth of their portfolio because: No one else is spread as thin. Only Juniper comes close and IMO and while i like SRX, it's not a while lot better than Firepower. Their ability to automate though? Leaps and bounds above cisco, and their hardware platform is arguable just as mature as any that cisco has on the market.

author: tendieshitter
body:
First off, visit [optionsprofitcalculator.com](https://optionsprofitcalculator.com) to get an idea what you would make with the move of an option. It's usually difficult to calculate given all the variables, but this site should help.

" say I expect the stock to hit $35.50 at some point that day and I would  sell it, I would want to buy a put option because I expect the stock to  go down on Monday. This protects me and provides me with the opportunity  to sell my 100 shares at $36.62 still, when the current price is  $35.50. Correct? "

No. If you expect a red Monday and you already own 100 shares of Cisco you plan to sell, you are already dealing with a loss. Furthermore, if you expect the price to go down further you would be good to buy a put contract on Cisco. 

If you want to hang on to your shares of Cisco because you expect them to go up, but want "insurance" against that, you could also buy a put contract in case the price goes down.

author: HallucinatoryFrog
body: I would buy if I was in your position.  Cisco is doing alright atm.  They are, however, at a crossroads where they are trying to decide how to move forward.  They've been on a straight tear in [acquisitions](https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/about/corporate-strategy-office/acquisitions/acquisitions-list-years.html) so if any of those pan out it could be big for them.  If you look at what each of those acquiring companies does though, it's all over the place.  SaaS, analytics, security, communications...I don't know if they're trying to be a jack-of-all-trades or if they are just throwing darts and seeing what sticks.

author: SUPER_swan
body:
The ESPP program you have is a great money maker for you.


Look at the last 10 years of the stock, not the last 6 months. Cisco has slowly gone up.


Lets say your required holding period is 1 year. That means if you hold the stock for 1 year and the stock doesn’t budge in price. If you sell you gain the 15% in the discount plus 4% from the dividend you gained as well. Historically, the stock has gone up as well, which also increase your gains.

So, continue to buy your company stock.


Now there is some people I bet at your work, just like mine, that have bought their company stock for 20+ years and never sold. Doing this increasing your exposure to that one company. If the company tanks, your stock will be worth a lot less and you could be out of a job.


However, if you go with selling right after your lock out period it’s a great way to use that discount to generate more money for you. 


Relax investing is a marathon not a sprint.

author: gamesterdude
body:
Tech consultant here.

This guy is right. Companies don't have capacity for large scale work from home if a bulk of their workforce is normally in the office. 

Sure you may always have been given VPN access, but most companies don't have enough capacity for everyone to use VPN at once. I typically see mid to large cap have capacity for about 30% of their workforce.

I think if you want to play this though you have to stagger calls on cisco to collect on the q2, and q3 up tick. Theta may be a big enemy on this one.

author: StrictPopcorn
body:
A bit of both. I’ve been using this time to sell off the stocks that I’ve been eying as underperforming and putting that money into stocks that are super down now so that I may see a good return instead of a continued loss even after the market recovers. 
I’ve also been increasing my dividend holdings significantly, I’ve been eying the airline stocks but for now I just have puts on a few airlines until I make a profit and put that money back into those stocks when I see a better sign of future growth coming for them. Right now they’re being hit harder than most stocks so that’s my thought behind it. 
TLDR:
What I’ve been doubling down in: MSFT, NRZ, AMD, PFE, AMT, CSCO & AAPL 
What I have puts on: JBLU, DAL, and sadly WEN (one of my larger holdings before the pandemic).

author: ams93482
body:
I think the issue is not doing any research before presenting a question. If, for example, you attempt an elementary level of stock analysis and summarize your thought process, while asking for feedback, that would be more appropriate. Simply stating "should I buy X, I have Y money" is somewhat lazy. Also, presenting questions in this fashion does not foster discussion in any meaningful way. 

To answer your question:

1. Microsoft, Apple, Google, Facebook, Amazon (Established Tech)
2. Ecolab, Honeywell, 3M, Corning, Cisco (Blue chip)
3. ETFs (i.e., VOO or VTI) 

Start here. See if you agree after researching. Additionally, I would wait to invest in Airlines/Travel due to the potential for bankruptcy.

author: espresso_inflective
body:
>I'm sorry, but people stuck at home won't be buying fewer Apple products to entertain themselves with, even if there is a delay in receiving the product from Apple, and Cisco won't stop building the internet that more people will use when they quarantined at home, and people won't go on Twitter less when they stuck at home, or buy less bandaids from JNJ, or stop buying laundry detergent from PG.

All of these are examples of demand shock, which I think most people agree is not the issue here. The issue is a supply shock: Apple is going to produce less, Cisco is going to have trouble obtaining their parts, Twitter's advertisers are going to experience similar shocks and buy fewer advertisements, and PG is going to have trouble sourcing the inputs for its laundry detergent.
